entry.title: Foodie Friday- Mexican Radio
entry.summary: So, the other day I was wondering:  am I on my A game? […]
entry.content:
So, the other day I was wondering:  am I on my A game? And if so, do I demand it of myself or do I surround myself with others who bring out the best in me.

Serious contemplations aside, this week’s trip was to the relatively new MEXICAN RADIO on State Street! I had been dying to go and had wanted to go when it was actually new but because it’s been so crowded as of late I couldn’t find the time to get in! I went on Wednesday night and who needs a reservation for two on a Wednesday night at like 7, right? You do, everyone does, and it is because it’s just that popular of a place.

And when I say popular, boy do I mean it. This restaurant is positively massive and it’s hopping’! It’s the third of it’s kind (there’s a Mexican Radio in NYC and in Hudson) and they have truly just about out done themselves.

The exterior of the restaurant is green and fun; a spicy look for the capital region! And inside the design only expands on the external color palette.

There are so many colors, you don’t know where to look. Oh, and if you do choose to explore ( like I did) as you walk through you’ll find that you just keep looking. The restuarant just goes on. Right when I walked in, I shrunk a little bit in comparison to such a large space and I’m already 5’0 so I guess I could order off the niños menu…

I could’ve but I didn’t.  I ordered off the normal menu. And as an appetizer there were Radio Roll-Ups and then Baja Fish Tacos and Calamari. And you can’t forget the variety of hot sauces! I’m not super into hot sauce, but they’re a main stay on every table. And you’ve got to live a little at places like these, right?

I’m definitely coming back and the goal is to occupy some of the prime real estate pictured below.

(Stole this off of Google because mine was too dark)

Whether Mexican Radio is the kind of restaurant that just wows all on its own with color and spice or it’s upped its game in order to sit on State St. amongst the many other great restaurants Schenectady has to offer, Mexican Radio was on its A game. And I guess that means I am too because you are what you eat.!

xo J

entry.title: Porches and Patios- Brown Bag It With J
entry.summary: Whether the day began with a bang where you felt like a […]
entry.content:
Whether the day began with a bang where you felt like a million bucks or with spilt coffee on a brand new outfit, lunch is the time to regain some strength, to change the pace, and lastly, to switch up the view.

I am working on campus this summer. And it’s a great job…but it’s also summer. In my mind summer entails endless sun, views for days, and some form of lounging/laying conveniently located near to some body of water (preferably, the ocean). But on a typical work day when I brown bag it, I free any hopes for the ocean and settle for the sun. Thus, I’ve managed to fit my sun-worshipping and lunching all into one little hour while occupying some of the best real estate this campus has to offer.

 

 

GRANT HALL

Grant has a porch to die for. It’s the type of porch that I imagined Noah would build for Allie (in The Notebook, of course) and to be perfectly honest I feel as though this building would have shown better. It has the aesthetic edge in and of its own right where as the other house has the distinct advantage of Ryan Gosling out front (see smaller picture.) But regardless, this porch, complete with an assortment of white adirondack chairs, is a prime lunch time spot.

 

Next, is MRS. PERKIN’S GARDEN

 

 

It’s a cute little seating area outside of Rathskeller, the pub-style food place on campus, but it’s just so pretty and such a great location to tan under the sun!

 

 

 

 

 

 

REAMER PATIO

The next place is attached to the back of the campus center, Reamer. It’s grand to sit beneath the cute and classic red and white striped awning or on the little stone wall I stood upon to take this picture. During the the end of the school (and on some of my more exhausting days) the grassy area in between is a nice spot that just looks like a slice of very green heaven. (The closest I come to dreamed-of beach.)

 GOLUB HOUSE

Some days, though, it’s an Adirondack chair and sunglasses kind of day. An easy breezy kind of vibe that demands an ease that only the recline of an adirondack chair can provide. There are the purple ones on the Golub patio or the classic ones that grace the front of Lamont, my home away from home.

LAMONT HOUSE

This is Lamont, my favorite place to be! I’m biased as a Classics major because this is home to that department alongside philosophy, religious studies, and anthropology. But, I reiterate, this is my favorite place and while it doesn’t get full sun exposure it remains a wonderful place to spend an afternoon and even watch some recreational tennis (there are courts just across the way.)

 

This is my personal little space that I’ve created for myself. It’s so picturesque, in fact, that I deemed it Instagram worthy and uploaded my personal setup -provided here.

(I hope you enjoyed my filter choice!)

 

 

As the day goes on, a change of space can change everything: your view, your attitude, and even your energy levels. And what the view can’t alter or enhance, the warm and glow-y of the sun can and will with some help from the fizz of some seltzer. Who knows where the day will take you ultimately, but be sure to stop here at any of these places for lunch.!

xo J

entry.title: Pay Day! -Zen and Beach Party
entry.summary: Sometimes the key is to just keep moving. Life is movin […]
entry.content:
Sometimes the key is to just keep moving. Life is moving and messy and doesn’t wait for anything-or anyone. So why do we? Life is in us and yet we defy its simple characteristics. Why do we hang in there and wait for that person to call, for tomorrow to come, or for that thing to just happen?

(COTTON CANDY! at the Summer Beach Party)

After a month of working hard, this past Friday was finally PAYDAY! And when $$ falls from the sky and drops into my bank account it’s akin to rain finally falling in the desert after a long, long drought. Thus, as any logical person would do when rain or $$ pours down from the heavens I celebrated alongside the other girls who work with me. We trekked over to State St., the main drag of downtown Schenectady, to dine at Zen. To add the the celebratory feel, we were surprised to discover the Downtown Schenectady Summer Beach Party already in full swing (at 5pm because we eat at old lady dinner time)!

Zen, is by far one of my favorite restaurants in the area. It’s perhaps a 5 minute drive from campus

(accessibility enhances its appeal) and it would be worth it even if I had to army crawl my way there. It serves Asian- fusion cuisine with beauty all around. From the white paper lanterns and parasols that grace the ceiling to the plating arrangements that they serve to you this place could not be any prettier. One almost hesitates to dig in and disrupt the artwork of food! But then again, thank goodness for the iPhone quick shutter and for Instagram to preserve your meal in all its glory while you dive into some of the best Asian food around.

(Sesame Chicken; Spicy Cali Roll and Rainbow Roll; Spider Roll and Alaskan Roll; The BEST Hibachi Rice)

There were 5 girls seated at this table and I, as the chatty little blogger you’re beginning to know, can honestly tell you sat there in silence as each one of us devoured the pretty plates above. The food is just that wonderful that you can’t even redirect your attention away from it once it’s hit the table top!  Delicious, affordable (although these girls just got paid!!), and a great place to spend a Friday. Once it progressed beyond old lady dinner time, Zen turned into a hopping spot, a testament to its quality.

On a typical night, Zen would hold me captive through dessert with my personal favorite choice being the coconut sorbet served in the shell amongst other fun listings such as fried ice cream or cheesecake. But tonight was a different night. There was a giant city summer party just outside the window and there was, most importantly, cotton candy across the way!! There was an entire street lined with various different vendors, primarily food based, ranging from the giant lemonade all the way to artisan fudge.

I focused in on the cotton candy and was having the time of my life, right next to all of the munchkins in the sand. What sort of operation would Schenectady be running if they had tried to throw a beach party without sand?! They even went the extra mile to include shovels, pails, and beach balls.

We wait because there are times when our due diligence pays off and does so in a big way. There may even be a sweet little bonus for those who work extra hard. Pay day can be rewarding and then all that waiting wasn’t so bad after all.

xo J

entry.title: Foodie Friday- Ambition Cafe
entry.summary: Welcome to Foodie Fridays! This is where I’ll bri […]
entry.content:
Welcome to Foodie Fridays! This is where I’ll bring you to some of the best places that Union loves to eat. And because I personally am I an avid foodie, I promise you that I’ll find a way to work it into other days of the week. I hope you’re hungry…

I read something the other day that read, “Be a flamingo in a flock of pigeons.” Tower in the midst of all those other common birds and flash some hot pink feather. Defy the ordinary and be a little funky.

So, today for lunch I decided to venture in to downtown for a lunch date with a friend. It’s a great way to break up the work day and on this particular occasion we found our way into Ambition Cafe located on Jay Street, a little pedestrian way in downtown.  This little cafe does decor like no other.!

There is seating to accommodate all desires. You can sit in a retro-feel red leather booth or toward the back where there are couches and a coffee table, creating the sense that you’re in someone’s home! But Madonna above the mantle and the dangling disco ball remind you that you’re not in just any home.

I ventured here today with my good friend Malu and we chose to sit in the front at a high top table. It was a great catch-up session for the two of us that was even crashed by John Travolta looking fresh in some disco attire with hair, that I hate to admit, rivaled my own for the day.

As the the very first picture in this post, the choice of wall art here draws you in and keeps you constantly fascinated.

I personally loved the retro-vibe, just as much as the food! The menu has pages of sandwiches each with its own name as well as other dishes. Malu ordered a chicken spinach wrap and I had a grilled brie and apple panini with cranberry-mustard! I, in complete sincerity, could have eaten four of those sandwiches and not because I walked in famished, but because they were just SO good!

(My lunch^^)

Not only does was the food stellar, but so was the waitress. She was kind and sweet. And the true testament to this description came when the check arrived. As a broke college student, I have learned to save and to hunt for a sale as if it were the last fresh water on Earth. But sometimes, I trade the savings for something that I view as qualitatively worthwhile. If I believe that it will greatly enhance my life (as ALL lunching tends to do), then I’m willing to splurge. But when the weather’s warm, I tend to forget that my bank account is not unlimited. So, I paid for my lunch in QUARTERS. Yes, quarters- neatly organized as pictured below. My waitress took it with a laugh and a smile, no judge-y looks or sass. She understood me; she knew. And man, was I thankful because I do not do “scenes” well anywhere, but especially in public. Additionally, I was entirely shameless about the entire affair; quarters still count as $$.!

All in all, it was such a great lunch. I hated to leave to return to work, but I’m not too concerned as I will return.  It was fun, good for a girl on a budget, and delicious!

With a sea of Starbucks to be found on every corner , Ambition is Union’s flamingo. In light of its definitively funky atmosphere, fun is to be had no matter the company. And while hot pink is sure to be a standout, at the end of the day a flamingo is still a bird- wings, beak, and all. Ambition is a hearken back to that local coffee shop flavor with a quirky sense of decoration to keep you entertained the entire meal.

xo J

entry.title: Hello, July!
entry.summary: Hello, July! …a week late. I guess I’m always a l […]
entry.content:
Hello, July!

…a week late. I guess I’m always a little late to the party, but so long as you make it there, that’s what counts.

Welcome to the second half of the year! This is the time to check in to think about all of those resolutions made back in January- watch less Netflix, eat healthfully, spend more time in the gym- and to reflect on the enthusiasm with which we began those efforts! This time of year, that kind of excitement and dedication appears much less frequently. So, I make July resolutions. And there are even festivities and fireworks to set the mood (although this fanfare is red, white, and blue!)

Thus, to all my new-found readers make yourself a new resolution for July (as stated above, it is never too late!) and while you go about that please join me in mine. I’ve decided to start blogging for my mid-year resolution. Envision it as the opening and closing of all your favorite (my favorite) television shows: insightful, relevant, and hopefully what you look forward to a the start of every day.

Prepare yourself to spend summer in Schenectady with me!

xo J

entry.title: dear graduating seniors,
entry.summary: If life were a book, Union would be my favorite chapter […]
entry.content:
If life were a book, Union would be my favorite chapter.

In the beginning, we – the protagonists – set out from our hometowns. For some of us that may have been three miles away in Niskayuna, for others that may have been three thousand miles away in California. Still others set out from the cool mountains of Tajikistan or the beautiful coasts of Canada.

The biggest challenge in those first few pages was making friends in a new place.  I, personally, felt like I could hardly handle it. Would people “get” me? How would I fare without the help of my identical twin sister? Could I ever find a group as awesome as my childhood crew? I think for all of us here at Union the answer to those questions has been a resounding “yes.”

Union’s community is seriously unparalleled. I am actually a transfer student to Union. I did my freshman year at another college. My biggest issue there was that people didn’t want to get to know each other.  Students approached the classroom like airport security; they wanted to get through as quickly as possible, with as little eye contact as possible, and without losing any baggage.

During my first visit to Union I saw a world of difference. Students came up to me asking, “Hey, how are you?” “Who are you?” and “What can I do to convince you to come to Union?” For me, that was enough. And in my three years of being here, through the ups and downs of school rankings, through the pros and cons of explaining to strangers just what exactly constitutes “upstate” New York, I have never once regretted my decision.

I – we – made friends at Union. We made unbelievable friends at Union, friends who would rally after a long week to go out to a party with us, friends who would drop everything to pick up a pint of ice cream from Reamer and join us for a much-need night in, friends who saw us at our worst with our heads in the toilet, and friends who saw us at our best presenting at Steinmetz or getting that long-deserved “A.”

We made more than friends at Union. We trekked up to frat row searching for them, we spent brunches at West avoiding them. We had nameless regrets and passionate pursuits that just never panned out.  We met people who taught us more about ourselves, and we met people who taught us more about themselves. Some pages of our chapter are marked with tears, while others feel like the beginning of perhaps another chapter.  Regardless of who we met, regret, or forget, these characters added pages to our chapter that we should never tear out.

Our Union chapters feel like the awesome montage scenes from movies before the ultimate reversal; the scenes where everything is going right for the protagonist, where the camera flashes from one magnificent victory to the next. This is what our Union chapters have felt like.

Our Union chapters are littered with scenes of Saturday Springfests and runs that end with a healthy dose of ribs and reggae. Our chapters include parties at multiple places referred to only by numbers and we’ve seen more dirty basements and dusty attics than we should probably admit. We’ve spent countless hours meeting with professors and even more time camped out in our lovely library.

I have never had so much caffeine in my life. I have never spent so little time sleeping and so much time napping. I have never read so much and I have also never skimmed so much. I know how to make ten dollars feel like one hundred and have figured out my best meal-swipe-to-declining-dollars ratio. I still remember when I stopped accidentally referring to my professors as teachers and began accidentally referring to my old grade school teachers as professors.

We all remember the first time we were invited to bowling on Erie. We all remember our first theme house party and how we slowly but surely figured out what exactly the Minerva system meant. We remembered how hard we worked for that “A” and how hard we worked for that “F.”

Our Union chapters have chronicled us from our time as fearful freshmen to our glory as successful seniors and we have changed for the better in the process. We’ve learned more than molecular biology, supply and demand, or Russian grammar – we’ve learned about who we are and understand a little bit better just how exactly we fit in this complicated world.

Next week I am going to miss waking up in a house of musicians, foodies, pilots, and track stars. I am going to miss chatting with professors after class and brainstorming with administration. I am going to miss sunsets behind West and walking by our big, beautiful, breathtaking Nott every single day. I am going to miss it all.

I am not afraid of starting my job in July. I am not afraid of moving to the city or figuring out how to manage a real-world budget. I am not even afraid of leaving the classroom – something I so love – because I know Union has set us up to be life-long learners.

No. I am most afraid of leaving this community. Next week I won’t walk home and say hi to my neighbors. Next week I won’t dash to class and run into a dozen friendly faces. I won’t spend two hours talking with a professor and I won’t trot into a dining hall alone knowing I will easily find a friend to eat with.

And I think it is universal for us – this feeling of fear, of not really knowing how we are going to handle what comes next – but as we move on to the next chapter of our lives, as we dot our “I’s” and cross our “t’s” and turn the last page, it is important to understand something about our time at Union; despite its wonderfulness, despite its brevity, our time at Union will always be our time at Union. That chapter will always be a part of our story and it will influence how we move forward.

Now, protagonists, it’s time to turn the page.

entry.title: Ending the Year Early
entry.summary: As I’m sure most people are aware, Union is on a […]
entry.content: As I’m sure most people are aware, Union is on a trimester system. This means our schedule doesn’t quite mesh with those of other academic institutions. Normally this doesn’t cause problem except for trying to meet up with friends over the breaks. However, I managed a land a REU for the summer, which is essentially a research internship. Despite special accommodations, I still have to leave Union a week early to start research elsewhere. This means taking all my finals early. To put it lightly, this wasn’t my favorite week at Union but at least the professors really made an effort to work with me. At any other institution this would be a huge issue. Here, they willingly arranged for an early exam period and just took my word that I’d not share the exam questions with my classmates. It’s really an advantage of the personal relationships that I have with my teachers.

entry.title: First Year In Pictures
in the next week…
entry.summary: By this point you probably have come to realize that I […]
entry.content:
By this point you probably have come to realize that I am quite the planner and live religiously by my schedule (see here and here), but this next week will probably be my craziest of college yet. Why? Not only do I have to hand in all of my final assignments for my classes (details below), but I have a twin sister who just happens to also go to a school on the trimester schedule which just happens to be 3,000 miles away in Southern California. Oh, and throw in there that the two of us will be turning 22 next week and that the whole family has to fly back to the east coast for my graduation by Sunday morning. No big deal, right?

Here’s how it will all (hopefully) pan-out:

Monday 6/9 — Attend a Phi Beta Kappa meeting, tutor a student in economics, submit my final portfolio for drawing (which includes handing in a completely full sketchbook… #ooohwerehalfwaythere)

Tuesday 6/10 — Present my thesis findings to the Admission Liaison Committee, hand in two 15-page+ papers for my two economics classes, move out of my apartment, spend the night at home for an early-morning wake up

Wednesday 6/11 — Fly six hours to LAX, meet up with twin at Caltech, try to be a real human being again

Thursday 6/12 — Turn 22!, celebrate with the family by going to Disneyland, head back to Caltech for a dinner with the president of the institute

Friday 6/13 — Watch my little sister (she’s two minutes younger… so naive!) graduate from the California Institute of Technology, thank God she survived her brutal four years there, add to those prayers that I don’t die of heat stroke during the outdoor ceremony

Saturday 6/14 — Head back across the U.S. to beautiful Schenectady (the winds will be in our favor this direction so that flight should only be five and a half hours — woohoo!!)

Sunday 6/15 — (GULP!) Graduate from my favorite place in the entire world, Union College

Surviving the next week should be a pretty major accomplishment. While part of me is definitely stressed about flying all over the place and embracing so many changes, I am so happy that I will have my friends and family there beside me the entire time.

Of course, the craziness doesn’t stop there; in the following month my little sister will graduate from high school, my cousin will graduate from high school in the city, we’ll have a giant graduation party in Hudson, NY, my twin will start working for Teach for America, I’ll move down to Manhattan, I’ll start my first full-time job, and I’ll fly to London for a month of training… It’s really not  a big deal at all (says the scared-y Cat who hates change…), but I think I’ll take it one week at a time.

entry.title: My Finals Playlist
entry.summary: There is nothing better than music for catalyzing study […]
entry.content:
There is nothing better than music for catalyzing studying. It relieves stress and allows for small escapes to make an hour feel like 5 minutes. I figured I would share my top ten study songs with the Unfiltered listeners to give you an idea of what my study pod sounds like during finals week.

1. Come With Me Now – Kongos

2. Road to Zion – Damian Marley and NAS

3. I Don’t Know – Kongos

4. White Room – Cream

5. Sunshine of Your Love – Cream

6. All Along The Watchtower – Jimi Hendrix

7. Enter Sandman – Metallica

8. Come as You Are – Nirvana

9. Lithium – Nirvana

10. Heartbreaker – Led Zeppelin

As you can see I love any and all types of rock, but the sound of Road to Zion is perfect for the occasional bit of reading that I have to do. I have always enjoyed listening to music and when studying it really is the only thing I need to get me through the hours.
